title: Were the Greek philosophers gay? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first thing you learn when you start to deal with the ancient world, in particular that of Ancient Greece & Rome, is that not only homosexuality was widely accepted, but wasn’t even defined, as same-sex relationships were as usual as the heterosexual ones. Actually, homoerotic love was depicted as philosophically higher, because it requires “real love” between two souls, a sense of affection that is detached from utility (make love in order to procreate). We have plenty of examples about this kind of relationships, starting from Socrates (who’s told to have been in a relationship with Alcibiades) to Alexander the Great, from Achilles to the poetess Sappho (whose poem about one of her students meeting her husband is heart-breaking) : He is more than a hero He is a god in my eyes —the man who is allowedto sit beside you — he who listens intimatelyto the sweet murmur ofyour voice, the enticing laughter that makes my ownheart beat fast. If I meetyou suddenly, I can’t speak — my tongue is broken;a thin flame runs undermy skin; seeing nothing, hearing only my own earsdrumming, I drip with sweat;trembling shakes my body and I turn paler thandry grass. At such timesdeath isn’t far from me. Eventually, even in Rome we’ve plenty of examples: Caesar (whose relation with the king of Bithynia, Nicomede, was the main topic of many gossips at the time), Nero, Hadrian and many others. Nevertheless, it wasn’t accepted as much as in Greece, as some Roman writers were used to describing it as “the greek vice”. What mattered in Rome was the position in the act: had someone had been active in the relationship, he wouldn’t have been discriminated. The passives, instead, were insulted. So, I guess plenty of ancient philosophers had homosexual relationships, even though not everybody wrote that in their philosophical works.

That’s an anachronism. “Gay” is a modern term. In most of Ancient Greece, same sex relationships between older men and teenage boys or between men was accepted as normal. The people who did this were not identified by any term that translates as gay. Some people in ancient Greece engaged in these practices, others did not. We don't know a lot about the lives of the Ancient Greek philosophers, though you can read about some of them in Plutarch (a fun read) or Diogenes Laërtius (not so much), among other places. As far as I can recall, and I'm not a classicist, we know a bit about Socrates, who was married to Xanthippe, a woman, but who had some sort of romantic, as we would say, relationship with Alcibiades, one of the leaders of Athenian political and military society. I don't think we know whether the relation was physical. About Plato or Aristotle, I don't think we have any real information regarding their sexual preferences or practices. I do note that Mary Renault, a historical novelist of Ancient Greece, a writer of real importance in my view, whose work is deeply scholarly—as far as I can tell when she depicts a person or a situation there is a historical basis for it—represent Plato personally disapproved of same sex relationships. (“Plato” was actually, as she points out, a nickname he acquired as a wrestler in his youth: his real name was Aristo-n.) That Mary Renault so depicts him this suggest to me there must be some basis for this. It's not the sort of thing she makes up.
